Changes to medical and family history:
Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
Vitals - T:97.9 BP:145/92 HR:124 RR:18 02 sat: 100%RA
GENERAL: agitated at times. Pt saying ""I want to go home,"" thin frail
SKIN: warm and well perfused, no rashes visible
HEENT: anicteric sclera, pink conjunctiva, patent nares, MMM
CARDIAC:  tachycardic, regular rate, S1/S2, no mrg
LUNG: coarse rhonchi, episodes of stridorous upper airway sounds
ABDOMEN: nondistended, +BS, diffusely tender, no rebound/guarding,
midline staples and j tube in place.
M/S: no cyanosis, clubbing or edema, no obvious deformities
NEURO:  Moving all ext spontaneously. No obvious focal deficits.
Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:13.4/52.5/1.1, Differential-Neuts:84.0 %,
Lymph:10.1 %, Mono:5.4 %, Eos:0.3 %, Ca++:10.0 mg/dL, Mg++:1.7 mg/dL,
RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 76**])
71-year-old white female with eophageal CA, admitted to NEB and
[**Hospital **] transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] for chemotherapy and XRT. She was
transferred to the [**Hospital Unit Name 4**] for respiratory distress and emergent bronch.
#. Respiratory Distress: Pt with y-stent and presents with acute
hypoxia. Pt with evidence of upper airway obstruction on exam
concerning for mucus plugging given secreations and cough or
malfunction of the Y-stent. Either malposition or obstruction.  Other
possibilites, but less likely include PE (pt with underlying
malignancy, but hypoxia was transient), pneumonia, PTX less likely
given uncchanged CXR. Pt is able to maintain states at 100%.
- Moxifloxacin per prior discharge for 2 more days
#. Leukocytosis: Pt has been afebrile. DDx inlcudes reactive
leukocytosis from aspiration pneumonitis. CXR did not show acute
- pt was previously on Moxifloxacin at time of discharge, will complete
2 week course. Hold on additional abx for now
#Agitation: Possible medication induced. Pt with paradoxical reaction
to ativan in the past per husband.  She did receive BZD this AM.
#. Tachycardia: Likely agitation and resp distress contributing. Pt was
tachy on admission to 110-120's. Also likely dry given poor po intake.
No ECG in record, but reportly sinus tach.
- IV fluids, gentle 250cc NS bolus then maintence
-will re-start tube feeds today if no further need for bronchoscopy
# Esophageal Ca: Chemotherapy per primary oncologist, Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 876**]. Plan was
to start chemo/XRT this admission.  Will follow-up with Onc.
t c/o nausea and no more dry heaves
# Pain management: Holding pain meds given respiratory distress for
now.  Will add back regimen after bronch and stablized.
Nutrition: Tube feeds to be re-started today
I saw and examined the patient and was physically present with the ICU
team for the key portions of the services provided. I agree with the
resident note, including the assessment and plan. I would emphasize and
add the following points:  71 yo F w/ remote breast ca s/p mastectomy
and chemo and recent dx of esoph SCca with TE fistula s/p esophageal
and bronchus Y stent 2 wks ago.  Admitted [**8-20**] for palliative chemo and
transferred to ICU yesterday w/ resp distress (desat to 75%, BP
stable but tachy to 160, refusing sx) for emergent bronch to eval stent
patency. She remains comfortable from resp standpoint since her
bronchoscopy. She has had transient agitation/confusion overnight.
Cachectic F somnolent, confused but able to follow commands, lungs are
clearer, still tachy, rr, +bs, soft, + J tube, no edema, warm ext
WBC 17 K, HCT 36, na 140, K+2.8 , Cr 0.4
CXR without focal infiltrate, flattened diaphragms, esoph stent visable
Her respiratory distress was most likely from plugging and has resolved
post-bronch. Agree with plan to continue chest PT, pulm toilet, nebs
with bronchodilators and mucolytics.  IP service is following. Continue
moxiflox through [**8-23**] for prophylaxis after stent placement.  She
continues to have a leukocytosos but remains af w/o obvious infectious
etiology. Will f/u on pending cx's.  She remains tachycardic, near her
baseline. Hypovolemia and possibly pain are likely factors. Continue
gentle fluids and resume TFs.  Her agitation and confusion is better.
If [**Name (NI) 4467**], would use haldol rather than benzos.  Additional onc
recs regarding her plan for pallitaitve chemo/c/s rad onc. Zofran for
nausea.  Will restart fent patch and half dose methadone for chronic
pain.  ICU:  R portacath, sq hep, PPI, full code, which will continue
to be addressed with onc team.
Remainder of plan as outlined in resident note.
Stable for floor transfer pending improvement in HR
------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) 143**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 144**], MD

The patient is a 71-year-old white female with esophageal cancer, who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory distress and emergent bronchoscopy. She has a history of breast cancer and chemotherapy. The patient presented with acute hypoxia and evidence of upper airway obstruction, possibly due to mucus plugging or malfunction of the Y-stent. Other possible causes include pneumonia, pulmonary thromboembolism, or pneumothorax, but these are less likely.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 97.9Â°F, blood pressure ranging from 112-160/60-90 mmHg, heart rate of 130 bpm, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 99% on 2 liters of oxygen. The patient is cachectic and somnolent but able to follow commands. Her lungs are clearer, and she has a positive bowel sounds. The patient has a central line, indwelling port (PortaCath), and a feeding tube in place.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 17,000 K/uL, hemoglobin of 36.1 g/dL, platelet count of 587 K/uL, creatinine of 0.4 mg/dL, and potassium levels within normal range. The chest X-ray did not reveal any focal infiltrate, and there is no"

,The patient is a 71-year-old white female with a history of esophageal cancer. She was admitted to the hospital due to respiratory distress and underwent an emergent bronchoscopy. The patient has been experiencing episodes of agitation, and there is a concern for medication-induced agitation due to a paradoxical reaction to ativan in the past. The patient's respiratory status remains unstable with coarse rhonchi and stridor, indicating possible upper airway obstruction or mucus plugging.

The patient has leukocytosis with a WBC count of 17.0 K/uL, which may be due to aspiration pneumonitis. However, the patient is afebrile and does not show any signs of pneumonia on the chest X-ray. Therefore, it is recommended to continue monitoring the WBC count and send blood cultures, urine cultures, and repeat the chest X-ray in the morning.
The patient also has tachycardia, which could be attributed to agitation, respiratory distress, or dehydration. An ECG should be obtained to further evaluate the heart rhythm.

In terms of management, the patient requires respiratory support with nebulized treatments and a pulmonary toilet. Antibiotic therapy with moxifloxacin should be continued for three more days. The patient's pain management regimen should be restarted after stabilization, including methadone, fentanyl patches, and Dilaudid PRN.
Additional recommendations include consulting with a nutritionist to restart tube feeds, continuing"

The patient is a 71-year-old white female with a history of esophageal cancer, admitted to the ICU for respiratory distress and emergent bronchoscopy. She was previously admitted to the NEB and another hospital for chemotherapy and radiation therapy. The patient's current conditions include respiratory failure, leukocytosis, pain control, tachycardia, agitation, esophageal cancer, and nausea/vomiting.

1. Respiratory Distress: The patient presents with acute hypoxia and evidence of upper airway obstruction, which could be due to mucus plugging, malfunction of the Y-stent, malposition or obstruction. Other possibilities include pneumonia, pulmonary embolism, or pneumothorax.

2. Leukocytosis: The patient has an elevated white blood cell count, which could be due to reactive leukocytosis from aspiration pneumonitis or another underlying cause. It is important to monitor the patient's condition and trends in white blood cell count, as well as follow up with blood cultures and urinalysis.

3. Agitation: The patient is experiencing agitation, which may be medication-induced. Possible causes include paradoxical reactions to benzodiazepines or poor pain control. Haldol has been ordered for agitation, and the patient's pain management regimen will be re-evaluated after bronchoscopy.
4. Tachycardia: The patient is experiencing tach"

The patient is a 71-year-old white female with a history of esophageal cancer, admitted to the ICU for respiratory distress and bronchoscopy. She was previously admitted to the NEB and transferred to [Hospital 1] for chemotherapy and radiation therapy. The patient presents with acute hypoxia and evidence of upper airway obstruction, concerning for mucus plugging or malfunction of the Y-stent. Other possibilities include pneumonia, pulmonary embolism, or pneumothorax. The patient is able to maintain oxygen saturation at 100%.

1. Respiratory Failure, Acute (not ARDS): The patient has respiratory distress with hypoxia and evidence of upper airway obstruction. An emergent bronchoscopy is planned to assess and clear any potential obstruction or malposition of the Y-stent.

2. Leukocytosis: The patient has an elevated white blood cell count, which could be due to a reactive response or aspiration pneumonitis. Monitoring of the white blood cell count and sending blood cultures and urine cultures is planned.
3. Agitation: The patient is agitated, possibly due to medication-induced effects. Holding on ativan and using haldol for agitation is recommended.
4. Tachycardia: The patient has a high heart rate, likely due to agitation, respiratory distress, and dehydration. An ECG and IV fluids will be ordered to further evaluate the cause.
- pt had episodes of n/v given zofran -> NPO, given D5,1/2NS bolus and
maintenance. Noted to have ?dystonic rxn (protrusion of tongue) with
- dilaudid 1mg q3h prn for break through, methadone increased to 40 tid
- haldol 0.5 IV at night with good effect
- oncologist (Dow) would like to start chemo today on OMED and get a CT

,The patient is a 45-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature 36.8Â°C (98.2Â°F), heart rate 123 bpm, blood pressure 160/81 mmHg, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on nasal cannula. The patient has a history of codeine allergy, nausea/vomiting, severe pain in erythromycin base, and anaphylaxis with Bactrim and penicillins. The patient is currently on various medications including pantoprazole, hydromorphone, haloperidol, and heparin sodium.

The patient's lab results show a white blood cell count of 17.0 K/uL, hemoglobin level of 11.0 g/dL, sodium level of 142 mg/dL, potassium level of 0.5 mg/dL, and a blood glucose level of 162 mg/dL. The platelet count is 587, creatinine level is 0.4, and the calcium level is 10.2 mg/dL. Other lab values include a PT/PTT/INR of 13.5/25.0/1.2, and differential white blood cell counts with neutrophils at 84.0%, lymphocytes at 10.1%, monocytes at 5.4%, eosinophils at 0.3%, and basophils at 0.1%.

The patient's medical complications include respiratory failure, leukocytosis, pain control, tachycardia, and potential complications related to his upcoming chemotherapy treatment. The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory distress, pain, and potential side effects from chemotherapy."

The patient is a frail and thin individual who is agitated at times. They have a history of multiple allergies, including codeine, erythromycin, penicillins, and aspirin. The patient has been experiencing episodes of nausea and vomiting, for which they were given Zofran and Reglan. However, the patient had a dystonic reaction to Reglan, so it was discontinued. The patient also received Dilaudid 1mg every 3 hours as needed for breakthrough pain, and their methadone dose was increased to 40mg three times a day. They were restarted on home remeron and received Haldol 0.5 IV at night, which had a good effect.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.8C (98.2F), heart rate of 123 bpm, blood pressure of 160/81 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on a nasal cannula. The patient's ABG results are ///28/. The patient has coarse rhonchi and stridor in their lungs, as well as diffuse tenderness in the abdomen without rebound or guarding. They have midline staples and a feeding tube in place. There are no obvious deformities in the patient's extremities or any cyanosis, clubbing, or edema.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC) of 17.0 and 16.4, hemoglobin (Hct) of 36.1 and 33.9, platelet count (Plt) of 587 and 505, creatinine (Cr) of 0.4 and 0.5, and glucose level of 162 and 142. Other lab values include PT/PTT/INR, differential white blood cell count, calcium (Ca++), magnesium (Mg++), and phosphate (PO4) levels.

The patient is diagnosed with respiratory failure, leukocytosis, pain control issues (both acute and chronic), and tachycardia. ICU care includes nutrition, glycemic control, lines management, prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) prevention."
- pt had episodes of n/v given zofran -> NPO, given D5,1/2NS bolus and

- dilaudid 1mg q3h prn for break through, methadone increased to 40 tid
- haldol 0.5 IV at night with good effect

The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for episodes of nausea/vomiting.

Vital signs show a temperature of 36.8Â°C (98.2Â°F), heart rate of 123 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 160/81 mmHg to 172/113 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient's heart rhythm is sinus tachycardia.

The patient has been experiencing respiratory failure, leukocytosis, pain control issues, tachycardia, agitation, and esophageal cancer. The plan includes addressing the respiratory distress by continuing nebs, monitoring the respiratory status, and considering a pulmonary toilet. Leukocytosis is being monitored, and antibiotics have been started. Agitation is being managed with haloperidol, and tachycardia is being treated with IV fluids and sinus tachycardia is being monitored.
